segments.text: Okay.
You want to just start by giving us the basic information on your rank.
Account name, rank, and service number.
Right.
Basically.
Name, John Niffin.
My rank in the Marine Corps was a sergeant.
I was in a tank unit, a Marine Corps tank unit, 3rd Tank Battalion, Bravo Company.
I went to Vietnam in 1965 and left Vietnam in 1968.
I went in the first time with the battalion landing team, 3rd Battalion, 9th Marines, which was the first unit that went into Vietnam when the buildup started in 1965.
Then I came out just after the Tet Offensive in 1968.
You volunteered, right?
I volunteered.
Nobody blamed but myself.
Okay.
Would you like to go into maybe why you volunteered to begin with?
This is essentially greed.
I was enrolled in A&M at that time and my grades weren't really good enough to qualify for any kind of scholarship.
So I talked to my local recruiter and he gave me this line about the naval enlisted scientific education program.
If I enlisted in the Navy or enlisted in the Marine Corps as a regular and I tested high enough on the qualification test that I would

continue to gain rank in the reserves, I would be able to go to college full-time with all my tuition, books, and living expenses paid by the government, and I would have a four-year obligation to the Marine Corps upon graduation as a commissioned officer.
So that sounded pretty good to me at the time, so I did it.
But then I found out that even though I tested

high enough on the test that they had, in 1965, they apparently suspended the NICEF program because they needed, I guess they needed more cannon fodder and less officers or maybe they were already getting enough officers.
At any rate, I ended up in Vietnam instead of back in college.
Right.
What was your perception of U.S. involvement early on in 1965?
the myth that if we didn't stop them in Southeast Asia, that they'd be putting their elephants in their sandpans and floating them across the Pacific Ocean and attacking San Francisco.
San Francisco next week.
Yeah.
I mean, you know, growing up in Texas and all that, I think I had the same phobia towards rampant communism as everybody else that's brought up in this state.
And at the time, it seemed reasonable.
And besides, you know,
Again, being brought up in Texas and on John Wayne movies and all that kind of stuff, I was sort of gobbled up with the warrior mystique.
Right.

Going over there, and either I'd get killed or I'd come back like Audie Murphy and have all kinds of medals and be able to go to Hollywood and make movies and never have to work for a living for the rest of my life.
Okay, I know that during Tet you were at Hawaii, right?
Well, initially, I came back just at the start of TEP.
Initially, I was at Quong Tree as part of a composite company.
So they had moved out a unit of Marines that was holding Quong Tree, the regular Marines.
And so they ran around and grabbed everybody they could find, the people that were returning from country for leave, cooks, messmen, supply clerks, everybody.
So we had sort of a composite company.
battalion of half Marines and half Navy Seabees at Quantry.
And then when we started to push into way, they discovered that I had a tanker MOS and the tank commander had been wounded in the way.
So I went in as his replacement.
And then after that I ended up trying to bust in the caseload.
Oh dear.
You described a little bit of the Battle of Hawaii to me.

I guess the thing that comes to mind primarily is this notion that there was some sort of a bloodbath, you know, that the Vietnamese or the NVA or the VC had to intimidate and use coercion on the people, the inhabitants of Guay.
That wasn't my impression.
My impression was that everybody in the city was against, you know, and I didn't feel they could get that sort of cooperation through force and intimidation.
And also, uh,
Initially, when we first got into Vietnam in 1965, we were allowed to go on liberty.
And so I'd been in the way on liberty and had visited the Citadel, which is the ancient capital and places like that.
And it was really beautiful.
There's a lot of art treasures and everything else in there.
And going in there with tanks and everything, we just pretty well destroyed the city.
At the time, I just didn't really care.
I mean, I had too many of my friends killed, and it didn't matter to me what I was doing to the Vietnamese people or their culture or anything else.
But in retrospect, it bothers me a little bit that I participated in destroying one of the cultural capitals of the world.
You said that then you were in Cape Town after that?
No, I wasn't in Khe Sanh.
That was part of the relief column.
It was a joint operation of the Marines in the 1st Cav.
It was trying to break through into Khe Sanh on Highway 9.
And it was 3rd Detainee, 4th Marines, I believe, 26 Marines was in Khe Sanh.
I was the tank support for the infantry unit that was trying to break into Khe Sanh.
Seems like from, you know, it's really fuzzy looking back at it this long.
It seems like it was from February to almost early summer, I'd say May or June before, you know, things were pretty passed by.
I mean, up until then, it was pretty much a free fire zone.
We couldn't operate except in, you know, great strength.
We'd get taken out.
Okay, by that time, troop strength in Vietnam was about at its peak.
I would say, yeah, about 10,000.
You're talking about 500,000 to 550,000 men in Vietnam.
What kind of differences in attitudes, or if any, did you see of the people that were coming in then from the 1 to the 10 early on?
I don't know if there's differences in attitudes in the 1 coming in, but you have to understand something that
The old salts didn't associate with the new guys.
You had your people that you'd been with for a while that you could depend on, and the new guys were an unproven quality.
Plus, you didn't want to make friends with somebody that might not be around the next day.
The newer arrivals, you didn't really care what their attitude was.
There was an attitude with the people that had been in the country for a while because before, you know, we were all going to go out and make contact with the enemy.
By this time, we were sort of at the opinion, heck with that, you know, we're going to stay alive.
So they'd send us out on these ambush patrols and things like that.
And we'd go up and set up just far enough forward of the wires that they wouldn't be able to hear us, you know.
play these John Wayne games anymore.
We're going to stay alive.
And that wasn't initially, you know, that was unheard of.
You know, we were, heck yeah, let's go out and fight and die for our country.
By 1968, there didn't seem to be as much of that.
The business, like what was happening later on, you know, as I understand the early 70s, you know, where units, whole units were refusing to engage the army.
You know, that wasn't happening.
It wasn't.
It was just local small units and squads and patrols.
And it wasn't that they flat-told their officers they weren't going to do it.
They just didn't bother to go where they were supposed to go.
One statement that's been made by a number of different people that have talked to our class in response to various things is the unique experience that everybody in Vietnam has
more group experiences in other situations.
It's a very, very personal war.
Everybody's experience is different.
As opposed to perhaps World War II, where you know who the enemy is, you know there's good and bad.
Did that hold with your experience during that time?
I'm not sure I really understand the question, June.

What has been said on several people that were there is that, I guess it's kind of a sociological thing, in some of the earlier wars where it was real clear what was going on, you knew who you were fighting, experiences of one person would not be that vastly different from those of another person.
Whereas, in Vietnam, everybody's experiences were so atomized and so different.
You might walk up on a little kid and be blown away.
You just don't know.
You know, I've heard a lot of those kind of stories.
I think there's one thing that did, people that didn't, that weren't Vietnami to realize,
You had several different theaters of operation, and my impression in talking to some of the Army people and things like that, that there were several different types of war going on.
For instance, I never got further south than Danau, and that was only coming in and going out.
Most of my time, my tour of duty was spent way up north, just below the Ben Hai River.
As a consequence, most of the troops that the enemy that we were engaged in were not VC.
They weren't little kids with hand grenades that you hear these stories about.
They were regular troops, more Vietnam troops.
And so, my way of thinking it was pretty much a traditional war.
Pretty much as much so as World War II, where you were engaging battalion and regimental and divisional size NVA units for the most part.

As opposed to, say, somebody that might be in the two-quarter area, you know, down Central Highlands, the middle of the country, that were dealing more with local VC units, you know, that were friendly farmers by day and VC by night.
You know, it wasn't that way.
There did...

I wouldn't say it's exactly a growing experience, but there was a change in attitude in that when I initially went over there, you know, like I said, it was all gung-ho, guiding country, home and corn, all that sort of thing.
And that didn't last very long, I'd say a couple of months.
And then it was just sort of marking time until I could do something neat like going on and on to Hong Kong or Sydney, Australia or something like that.
And then you, and real close partner, get blown away, you know, and then it was a revenge trip after that, you know, you just wanted to waste goose.
And I know that was my evolution, I can't say that, you know, that I was, I feel I was typical, but then, you know, everybody likes to feel that they're reborn, you know.
That's the way I, my experience, you know.
But also, you know, since I was there from 65 to 68, I saw different phases of the war.
You know, from the beginning in 1965, our mission principally was the defense of the denying airstrip.
And I really had the impression that the VC, I don't know if they even were in the NBA,
the Americans.
They just wanted to leave us alone.
And then towards 66 and 67, things got a little more serious.
We weren't making a lot of contact within the units.
My attitude sort of changed correspondingly.
But initially it was a big joke.
Here I am over in the combat zone.
We're not having fun.
I get free mail and privileges.
I don't have to pay income tax.
All I have to do is write three of my letters to send it home.
It was great.
And that all changed pretty rapidly.
Yeah.
Well, I'd say it changed very rapidly.
By August 1965, the Marines had engaged just south of Chula.
I think it was called Operation Starlight.
And from then on, I guess the Vietnamese finally realized that we weren't going to go away by just ignoring us.
So from then on, our bases in Da Nang and other places like that were being mortared and later rocketed.
We were getting mines and booby traps and things like that in the bills.
And then after I moved up north,
Okay, let's get into a little bit of your involvement in the VDAW after you moved back.
How did you get involved in that and why?
How did your perceptions change by the time you got involved with the VDAW?
You know, when I first got back, I thought I was some kind of a psychotic.
I was real isolated.
I was going to school in Houston at San Jacinto Junior College, but I just felt no rapport whatsoever with the other students.
I didn't really want to socialize with them.
I didn't want them to know I was a veteran because I didn't want to have to defend my position while I was in Vietnam and all that kind of stuff.
And I guess the first thing that really disturbed me is I came back.
Marine Corps at the end of July of 1968.
So I was back in Houston working for the phone company and trying to go to school by August when the conventions were over.
And watching what was going on at the Democratic Convention was just really upsetting to me.
I mean, if I had been fighting in Vietnam for freedom and democracy for the Vietnamese people, then what in hell had happened in my country while I was gone, you know, when you can see
and stuff like that.
But I still wasn't, I would say, a really political person.
That didn't really occur until
1971, when the Vets, what later became VVAW, went to Washington, D.C. and won three of the medals.
That just really impressed me.
And, you know, I've met Kathy and married by then.

She was telling me, instead of just sitting back there cussing the television set every night, you know, when Nixon would come on and talk about what a wonderful job we were doing over there, maybe I'll think about getting involved in doing things.
I just...
didn't really want to do it, I had tried to participate in the first student mobe anti-war march, which I guess was in 1969 in Houston.
And I told them that I had some photographs of way, and that they could compare these photographs with photographs of Life magazine, and they could see the kind of damage
The response I got from these enlightened campus radicals was that they really didn't want any form of professional killers in their peace march.
And I said, OK, it's fine with me.
So I just pulled in my horns and went back to work for the phone company.
And that's pretty much where I was until the BVAW Dewey Canyon III business.
And then after Dewey Canyon III, this individual I was telling about, Terry DeVoe,
I was wandering around campus at UT with those signs that said, Vietnam vets, please talk to me, trying to get people involved in VBAW.
And they were fixing to do a dedication at the LBJ library.
So we had a meeting in Austin, and Kathy talked me into going down there.
So I got together with these people.
At first, I was appalled by some of them.
I mean, some of the people that were there, I don't know whether they were police agents or what, but some of the suggestions of an agent
I mean, there was one guy that wanted to go to a simulated guerrilla theater, you know, and attack the LBJ library, you know, and throw smoke bombs and firecrackers.
And I just did not think that was a good idea at all, you know, with the president and everybody else on hand, you know.
Throwing anything that goes bang at them just seemed like a real good way to get a whole lot of people killed.
But Kerry was a really exceptional individual, and he and I had sort of an instant rapport.
Later, he ended up coming over to my house, and we silkscreened a whole lot of DBAW banners at our house for the demonstration.
Got to talking, found out through his experiences and my experience.
He's from Brownfield, Texas.
Somebody grew up in Del Rio, Val Verde County.
Both of us coming from West Texas.
We had a pretty good rapport.
We both knew where our heads were when we got over there.
When had he been in?
He had, I'm not sure exactly.
He was a Army, he was a Lieutenant for Green Berets, and I believe he'd been over there essentially the same time as I had.
I'm not sure the exact date, so.
Yeah, pretty early.
Well, this was 1972, you know, and he already had long hair and a beard, so he'd been out for a while.
I think he got back approximately the same time I did, maybe.
Well, we wanted to go throw our medals away.
Well, first of all, you know, that's the first experience I had with the counterculture politics.
You know, I was not even left to believe that if you were against the war, you know, that you were all on the same side.
And so we were encountering what they call the trots, the Socialist Workers Party and all their people.
And they were trying to co-opt everybody for their demonstration.
And then, you know, VBAW
because of the business in Washington, D.C., you know, all the other movement organizations sort of wanted to get there, you know, and there seemed to be some kind of a catch.
So everybody was tugging at us, you know, and we were all kind of like we were being pulled from one side to the other.
And I don't think any of us had any real clear-cut politics, you know.
I mean, we weren't Marxist, we weren't Socialist, you know.
We weren't even good Democrats or Republicans.
We were just out there.
So, we finally decided we were just going to divorce ourselves from all these groups and do our own thing.
We discussed the possibility of civil disobedience, but non-violent civil disobedience.
We didn't want to get in trouble.
We wanted to make our point, and if there were, like for instance, there was an injunction going that supposedly limited us, I think a half a mile from the LBJ library or something like that.
So we just decided, well, that's a crock, you know, that's clearly unconstitutional.
So we weren't doing a baby injunction.
That was one of the points the trots were making.
We were going to get everybody arrested if we crossed the deadline.

But we approached the barricade and talked to some Secret Service people and told them what we were there for and that we had no intention of threatening anybody, you know, but we didn't want to make a political statement.
We wanted to turn our decorations in.
He says that there's no way that we weren't going to cross the barricade.
He says, well...
about if we delegate one individual and all you guys can escort him up there and he can act on behalf of all of us.
So that's not going to work either.
So, you know, there is some talk about, well, let's force the barricade, and we finally decided that wasn't going to be productive, so we just chunked our mills across the barricade.
The Secret Service was busy collecting them all up, and I guess Tech and Cereal is going to be staying to find out who we're going to work with.

And after that, after spending the day at the LBJ library and watching people getting tear gassed and cops chasing people down the street, my wife and I ended up going on a run with a bandito's motorcycle.
So there were some problems there that day.
I wouldn't say it was any serious problems, but there were a few people that were throwing things, and the cops were responding.
There was some tear gas set off at one point.
I don't really know how many people were arrested, but it wasn't any of the big mass arrests that occurred later on.
The first one I ever did, I guess, I can't say whether it was typical or not for the time, but it seemed pretty typical.
In general, it was pretty peaceful.
Were you involved in the VVAW even ongoingly after that?
Well, I sort of got conned into taking the position initially
the resource person for the local University of Texas, and then later the Austin chapter coordinator of Vietnam Veterans Against the War.
And then Terry, by that time, was having some problems.
And so in December of 71, Terry resigned.
And I found myself as the state coordinator for the regional coordinator.
Did you ever have any personal problems arise as a result of that?
Oh, yeah.
In fact, all of my arrest records all stem from my involvement with the VAW.
Initially, on Veterans Day 1971,
We were arrested for parading without a permit on the sidewalk in Killeen.
And then later in 1972, when they started the offensive, the Vietnamese started their 1972 offensive.
And Nixon was telling everybody that he'd do anything to stop the Vietnamese incursion in the south with the exception of reintroduction of ground troops and the use of nuclear weapons.
VVAW had a lot of guys in active duty, you know, that were soul brothers of the organization.
So they were telling us, you know, we were getting these calls from all these military bases and they were telling us what their alert status was, what their deployment status was.
And when you put it all together, it became very apparent that what was happening was that Nixon was...
started compiling all this as sort of an organizational thing.
And that started a bunch of demonstrations.
And I got arrested for aggravated assault on a police officer in one of those demonstrations in Austin.
And then it sort of culminated in a conspiracy case.
BVAW was planning to attend the Democratic National Convention.
I can't speak for the organization, but I myself had no intention of going to the Republican Convention.
What was the point?
We all knew who the Republican candidate was going to be.
And whereas you might be able to influence the Democratic candidates, there was no way you were going to change Nixon's mind.
So we were holding meetings and discussing what to do about the Democratic convention.
And it was decided that we would have a convoy from...
There was essentially three branches, one coming down the east coast, one coming across from the west coast, and one coming down from the midwest off of Virgin and Florida.
We called it the last patrol.
We'd go to the convention.
We were having meetings and discussions on this.
One of our meetings was infiltrated by an agent provocateur, a guy named Bill Linger.
saying we knew we were on trial for conspiracy, but the government's charge was that we were inspiring to disrupt the Republican convention.
And the grand jury sat during the Democratic convention, so all of us were...
It exactly coincided with the Democratic Convention.
Our subpoenas ordered us to appear at the day the Democratic Convention started, and we were released from subpoena when the government had the nomination.
So we were held in Tallahassee at the other end of the state, all the leadership.
And I sort of felt like the government felt that VBAW was like
IBM or something.
If you get the board of directors and take them off someplace, then you cripple the company.
Since VBAW didn't work that way at all, we were a bunch of anarchists.
The mere fact that you held the regional coordinators someplace didn't change one bit what was going on with the organization because they were still doing what they wanted.
The government had it conspiratorial.
But at any rate, they ended up charging us with a conspiracy to cross our state lines to decide a riot at the Republican National Convention.

And they said that as part of that conspiracy that we were going to use slingshots and cherry bombs and fried marbles and crossbows against highly assembled police and military power at the convention.
In other words, you know, we were going to be down there shooting at the 82nd Airborne and the FBI and the Dade County Sheriff's Department, you know, with slingshots and crossbows.
I was, save one of the defendants, had been in the military and had served in Vietnam.

I've got to say one thing about the government, they do teach you how to use all these neat weapons, you know, so why couldn't they come up with anything better to use than stone shots, cherry bombs, crossbows, and pride marbles?
But at any rate, they went ahead with this farce, you know, and screwed around for a year with motions on motions to suppress motions and things like that.
Finally put us on trial about a year later, and after about a month-long trial, the jury came back with an earnest verdict of acquittal, and we were all cut loose.
It was held in Gainesville, Florida.
Everybody was acquitted.
Which is good because the way conspiracy works, if they had managed to convict one of us, they would have convicted us all.
Conspiracy is not a crime as much as a thought, which makes it so dangerous.
So if they had been able to prove that one of us had committed a crime, then that could have convicted us all.
That's the whole thing about conspiracy.
You know, I often thought when they tried Mitchell and Stans for conspiracy, you know,
The government had lost all their other conspiracy cases, you know, the Chicago case, the Oregon case, and the Seattle case, and our case.

I often thought that some hot shot lawyer in the Justice Department was sitting there saying, you know, we've got to try and mention them stands for something the American people want most, and let them off for nothing.
So somebody says, well, let's try them for conspiracy.
We never won on that one before.
And lo and behold, the first time they get a conviction on conspiracy is against Mitchell and Stanton.
Sort of an ironic justice thing.
But did that case have a name?
Yeah.
